title: Elimination of inrush current in parallel transformers by sequential phase energization
abstract: Production of very high inrush currents in transformers during energization may create deep voltage sag causing malfunction to electronic and other loads. In high voltage power system star-delta transformers are generally switched in, one by one, producing inrush currents each time. The inrush current may be reduced by sequential phase energization of each transformer with neutral resistors.\n\nThis paper suggests that sequential phase energization should be carried out on the first transformer only after paralleling the delta secondary of all the transformers. This procedure eliminates inrush currents in all the remaining transformers without too much increase in the inrush of the first transformer.

Abstract: Production of very high inrush currents in transformers
during energization may create deep voltage sag causing malfunction
to electronic and other loads. In high voltage power system star-delta
transformers are generally switched in, one by one, producing inrush
currents each time. The inrush current may be reduced by sequential
phase energization of each transformer with neutral resistors.
This paper suggests that sequential phase energization should be
carried out on the ﬁrst transformer only after paralleling the delta
secondary of all the transformers. This procedure eliminates inrush
currents in all the remaining transformers without too much increase
in the inrush of the ﬁrst transformer.
Keywords: inrush current, sequential phase energization, star-delta
transformer
Classiﬁcation: Science and engineering for electronics

1 Introduction
Star-delta transformers are commonly used in power transmission and dis-
tribution system to interconnect diﬀerent voltage levels of the power system.
Generally the star side is solidly grounded. Such transformers are usually
connected in parallel to supply the distribution loads.
Production of high inrush current in a big transformer during switching
in the supply always creates a big power quality problem. The transient
voltage dip may cause motor tripping, mal-function to electronic loads and
protective relays etc. Energization of the transformer from the star side
allows the control of neutral resistor utilizing the advantage of unbalancing
in the 3-phase inrush current and sequential switching of phases to achieve the
reduction of inrush current [1, 2]. Sequential switching with optimum value
of neutral resistor may reduce the inrush current to a lower value, but the
system experiences the inrush during the energization of each transformer.
This paper suggests that the delta secondary of all the transformers
should be connected in parallel before applying sequential energization of
the ﬁrst transformer. This procedure eliminates inrush currents completely
for subsequent switching in of the remaining transformers without any sub-
stantial increase of inrush in the ﬁrst transformer.
2 Sequential phase energization
Fig. 1. Two transformers connected in parallel
In Fig. 1 two star-delta transformers are connected in parallel to supply
the distribution loads. During normal operation star neutrals are solidly
connected to ground. The conventional way of energizing each transformer
is to switch on the supply to the star-side by closing the respective circuit
breakers (CB) one by one, thereby, creating very high inrush current as high
as 10 to 12 times the full load current each time. Then the delta-side CBs
are closed. The peak value of the inrush current depends on the instant of
switching, winding resistance and residual ﬂux in the core. A large number

of literatures [3, 4] reported the production and control of inrush currents in
single and 3-phase transformers by series resistance insertion, point-on-wave
switching etc. But their applications in high voltage high power transformer
are limited due to practical considerations.
The inrush current in each transformer may be reduced by about 80
to 90% by connecting neutral resistor of suitable value to the star winding
neutral of each transformer and sequentially switching the phases.
The steps of sequential switching are:
1. Energize any one phase (say phase-a)
2. After a short delay (about 5 cycles) when current in phase-a stabilizes,
phase-b is closed.
3. After another short delay of about 5 cycles when currents in both a
and b phases are stabilized, phase-c is closed.
4. Finally the neutral resistor Rn is shorted by closing the switch S.
It is well known that modern high voltage circuit breakers have a built-in
mechanical delay among three phases or independent operating mechanism
for each phase. So the implementation of the scheme is not diﬃcult.

High value of Rn produces low inrush current and the steady state current
is reached within a very short time as the time constant (2Lo/3Rn) is low.
At the instants of switching in phase-b and phase-c the magnitude of
contact voltage diﬀerences ∆Vb and ∆Vc across the CB contacts should be
low to produce low value of inrush currents. In reference [2] it has been
shown that Rn ≈ 0.085 Xo produces minimum steady state magnitude of
∆V
b=∆Vc ≈ 0.68E. So, this value of Rn may be chosen for sequential phase
energization. When all the three phases are energized the neutral current
becomes very low and shorting of Rn may not produce any transient current.
Energization of each transformer by sequential switching is not only a
complex procedure but also produces some inrush current in each case.
The disadvantages of the conventional sequential switching scheme are:
a) The complex procedure of sequential switching is to be followed for
each transformer at the time of energization of each of them.
b) Some inrush current is produced at the time of energization of each
transformer.

3 Proposed scheme
Before energizing any transformer all the delta secondary are connected in
parallel. CB3 and CB4 (refer Fig. 1) are closed ﬁrst and the neutral of TR2
is solidly grounded and Rn2 becomes redundant. The sequential switching
operation is now carried out on TR1. If 2 transformers having the same
rating are connected in parallel, then the equivalent open circuit reactance
becomes Xo/2. Therefore, the optimum value of Rn should be half of the
previous value. So the inrush current in all the phases of TR1 increases to
some extent during sequential switching in comparison to those values for
energizing TR1 with isolated secondary. The delta winding voltages of TR1
and TR2 are equal as they are connected in parallel and are proportional
to supply voltage after Rn is shorted. So, the induced star-side voltage of
TR2 becomes equal to the supply voltage. Subsequent closing of CB2 does
not produce any inrush current in TR2. Similarly, if all the delta secondary
of more than 2 transformers are connected in parallel, sequential switching
produces some inrush current in TR1 only. The inrush current is completely
eliminated during closing of star-side CBs of the remaining transformers.
The advantages of the proposed scheme are:
a) The sequential switching is to be carried out only on the ﬁrst trans-
former to be energized and some inrush current is produced only once.
b) The remaining transformers are directly switched on without producing
any inrush current.

4 Simulation results
Two star-delta transformers having a rating of 12 kVA, 400 V/115 V, 50 Hz
each is used for simulation study to verify the validity of the proposed scheme.
The winding resistance and no-load reactance of each transformer are 0.37
and 422 ohm per phase respectively. Magnetization curve with deep satu-
ration data of a silicon-steel core is used for the simulation. A MATLAB
program is prepared for the simulation study. Neutral resistor of 36 ohm
(≈ 0.085x422) is used for sequential phase energization of one transformer
with isolated secondary and 18 ohm is used with two secondary in parallel.
Time delay of 0.1 second (5 cycles in 50 Hz system) is used between consecu-
tive switching operations.

The peak inrush is about 50% of full-load current (17.32 A) while ener-
gizing one transformer with isolated secondary and approximately 72% with
delta windings in parallel. Simultaneous closing of all the phases without any
neutral resistor produces inrush 3.3 times the full-load current. The voltage
diﬀerence between the source voltages of each phase with the star-side in-
duced voltages for parallel delta energization is about 0.15% of the source
voltage (230√2 V peak per phase). It justiﬁes the validity of the proposed
scheme as no inrush current will be produced while closing CB2 with so small
volt diﬀerence. Simulation results of star-delta transformers each having a
rating of 50 MVA, 132 kV/33 kV, 50 Hz also validate the proposed scheme.
5 Conclusion
Huge magnetizing inrush currents are produced during energization of large
transformers creating voltage sag to cause mal-function to electronic and
other loads. Sequential phase energization in star-delta transformer with op-
timum value of neutral resistor may reduce the inrush current substantially.
However, some inrush current is always produced while energizing each trans-
former in a group of transformers. Application of sequential switching to only
one transformer after connecting all delta-secondary in parallel may eliminate
inrush current during subsequent energization of the remaining transformers
without any substantial increase in inrush of the ﬁrst transformer. This tech-
nique also restricts the application of complex process of sequential switching
and the use of neutral resistor to one transformer only.
